natural problem:
For a real number $x,$ let
\[f(x) = \max \{|x + 15|, |x + 12|, |x + 8|, |x - 1|, |x - 3|, |x - 19|\}.\]Find the minimum value of $f(x).$
natural solution: We can think of $|x + 15|$ as the distance between $x$ and $-15$ on the real numbers line, and $|x - 19|$ as the distance between $x$ and 19 on the real number line. [asy] unitsize(0.2 cm); draw((-25,0)--(25,0));
By the Triangle Inequality, the sum of these distances is at least $19 - (-15) = 34,$ which implies that at least one of $|x + 15|$ and $|x - 19|$ is always at least 17.
Therefore, $f(x) \ge 17.$ Note that $f(2) = 17,$ so the minimum value of $f(x)$ is $\boxed{17}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = Max {abs (x + 15), abs (x + 12), abs (x + 8), abs (x - 1), abs (x - 3), abs (x - 19)}"
shows  "Min {f x |x. True} = 17"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

\[f(x) = \max \{|x + 15|, |x + 12|, |x + 8|, |x - 1|, |x - 3|, |x - 19|\}.\]Find the minimum value of $f(x).$ The final Answer is 17
 ### Proof
 We can think of $|x + 15|$ as the distance between $x$ and $-15$ on the real numbers line, and $|x - 19|$ as the distance between $x$ and 19 on the real number line. [asy] unitsize(0.2 cm); draw((-25,0)--(25,0));
 draw((-15,-0.5)--(-15,0.5)); draw((19,-0.5)--(19,0.5)); draw((4,-0.5)--(4,0.5)); label("$-15$", (-15,-0.5), S); label("$19$", (19,-0.5), S); label("$x$", (4,-0.5), S); [/asy]
 By the Triangle Inequality, the sum of these distances is at least $19 - (-15) = 34,$ which implies that at least one of $|x + 15|$ and $|x - 19|$ is always at least 17.
 Therefore, $f(x) \ge 17.$ Note that $f(2) = 17,$ so the minimum value of $f(x)$ is $\boxed{17}.$
 *)

fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = Max {abs (x + 15), abs (x + 12), abs (x + 8), abs (x - 1), abs (x - 3), abs (x - 19)}"
